conclusion: Need to analyze the v-t graph and its derivatives to determine if the particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds.
The v-t graph shows the velocity of the particle as a function of time.
A straight line on the v-t graph indicates constant acceleration, while a curve indicates changing acceleration.
Focus on the time interval from 1 second to 2 seconds.
From 0 to 1 second, the velocity increases linearly, indicating constant positive acceleration.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the velocity curve starts to level off, indicating decreasing acceleration.
From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly, indicating constant negative acceleration.
Acceleration is the derivative of velocity with respect to time, and the slope of the v-t graph gives the acceleration.
At t = 1 second, the slope of the tangent to the curve is relatively steep.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the tangent lines become less steep, indicating decreasing acceleration.
The red lines in the second image represent the tangent lines at different points between 1 and 2 seconds.
The slope (acceleration) is decreasing as time progresses within the interval from 1 to 2 seconds.
The particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds.
